üö®Re-read Alert üö® 

üíê It Ends With Us
‚úèÔ∏è @colleenhoover
 
I am never a re reader but I read this one years ago and wanted to remind my brain before I dug into her newest release- #itstartswithus üíô

This was just as good as I remember, but honestly I don‚Äôt remember a lot of it so it was almost like I had never read it before! All the emotions! üò≠

This book is so dang good and so important. If you took the extra time to read the authors note at the end then you already know that some of the events were based on Colleen‚Äôs mother‚Äôs life. The authors note was one of the most emotional parts of the book for me! How brave to share that with us! üíï

I have also now finished It Starts With Us and can‚Äôt wait to share my thoughts on this one! üòä

Hm, why did anyone not warn me about this book? I was expecting a cute romcom holiday book, but that‚Äôs not what I read.

Full warning, this book is not a romcom book. It‚Äôs a very heavy book that make you sad. It‚Äôs unexpected yet messy at the same time. 

Spoiler Alerts: there are major trigger warning such as death of parents, death of a loved one, cheating, terminally illness, and grief.

#qotd Have you read any controversial thriller book(s)?
I AM PILGRIM- Terry Hayes 
GENRE: #thriller #mystery #crime #contemporary #suspense #fiction 
MY RATING: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
SYNOPSIS:
This book is mainly about a CIA agent on a mission to prevent a terrorist attack from happening. In between, comes the life of the agent and life of the terrorist as well. It‚Äôs more of chasing rather than mystery. It is the whole journey of the agent of figuring out not only the terrorist but also his life. Basically there are five important events that is bound strangely by a subtle thread, which gets unraveled by the agent. 
MY REVIEW:
Pace- The pace was fast. Not too much though. As mentioned there are many events happening but the author didn‚Äôt write it in a complex way. It was easy to catch up and remember.
Language- The narration was perfectly lucid. The author mentioned some political aspects but those were too in a non-complicated way. 
Plot- The plot was intriguing and building from the very first chapter. It was not monotonous for a single moment. 
The plot writing was a little similar to Dan Brown‚Äôs. Just a little. However, it was an easy read unlike the complexity of Brown‚Äôs. 
Character development- In between all the chaos of solving murder, terrorism attack stress, the author explained the life of the protagonist and also the terrorist. However, I felt like, it was this constant rivalry between Americans and the Muslims. 
Climax- The climax did give a closure. However, it ended in such a way that if the author wants, he can write a sequel. 
I give this 4 stars because I was not bored for a moment, the book caught my attention from first to last and not for a moment I thought to DNF it. 
FROM: @crescent_books.bd
You may check my more detailed review in goodreads.

I Know Where You Live ‚ú®REVIEW‚ú®
By Gregg Olsen

Thank you @netgalley for the arc of this book. 

I listened to an audio book written by Gregg Olsen a while ago and it was brilliant. I‚Äôve been keeping an eye out for anything written by him ever since so when I saw this was available on NetGalley I requested it straight away. 

However, this book was a struggle to read and should come with a warning on the first page. TW: rape, grooming, sexual assault, sexual abuse, child abuse, child sexual assault‚Ä¶ you get my drift‚Ä¶

The writing style was fine, characters fine but the plot was so heavy I found it hard to read much at a time and I didn‚Äôt find myself wanting to pick it up, it was almost a chore to read. 
I‚Äôve read books with heavy topics before, but there was just so much in this book. 

I do still want to read more by this author as I really loved that first audio. This one was just a bit to heavy for me. 

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

I Know Where You Live will be published November 15th.

#coffeeandcurrentlyreading 

I just started this tomb of a book and have fallen right back into Backman‚Äôs hands when it comes to my emotions.

Page 1 did me in!

Synopsis:

Over the course of two weeks, everything in Beartown will change. 

Maya Andersson and Benji Ovich, two young people who left in search of a life far from the forest town, come home and joyfully reunite with their closest childhood friends. There is a new sense of optimism and purpose in the town, embodied in the impressive new ice rink that has been built down by the lake.

Two years have passed since the events that no one wants to think about. Everyone has tried to move on, but there‚Äôs something about this place that prevents it. The destruction caused by a ferocious late-summer storm reignites the old rivalry between Beartown and the neighboring town of Hed, a rivalry which has always been fought through their ice hockey teams.

Maya‚Äôs parents, Peter and Kira, are caught up in an investigation of the hockey club‚Äôs murky finances, and Amat‚Äîonce the star of the Beartown team‚Äîhas lost his way after an injury and a failed attempt to get drafted into the NHL. Simmering tensions between the two towns turn into acts of intimidation and then violence. All the while, a fourteen-year-old boy grows increasingly alienated from this hockey-obsessed community and is determined to take revenge on the people he holds responsible for his beloved sister‚Äôs death. He has a pistol and a plan that will leave Beartown with a loss that is almost more that it can stand.

As it beautifully captures all the complexities of daily life and explores questions of friendship, loyalty, loss, and identity, this emotion-packed novel asks us to reconsider what it means to win, what it means to lose, and what it means to forgive.

QOTD: which is your favourite Backman novel and if you haven‚Äôt read him then what are you currently reading?

The thirst: Jo nesbo
A woman is found murdered after an internet date. The marks left on her body show the police that they are dealing with a particularly vicious killer. Under pressure from the media to find the murderer, the force know there's only one man for the job. But Harry Hole is reluctant to return to the place that almost took everything from him.

Take My Hand 
By @dolenperkinsvaldez 

This was our October book club pick and I was excited since I got it as a BOTM pick a bit ago. 

This story is so fitting with the climate of the country right now and the fact that our bookclub is a group of wonderful registered nurses!

I am exactly halfway though, I started this morning, and I don‚Äôt want to put it down. It‚Äôs not a light read, and you might want to keep a box of tissues near, but I think it‚Äôs a story that needs to be told. 

Full review to come!

‚ÄúI will wonder if the memories that remain with age are heavier than the ones we forget because they mean more to us, or if our bodies, like our nation, eventually purge memories we never wanted to be true.‚Äù

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

This is a memoir written as a letter to the author‚Äôs mother. It‚Äôs about the author‚Äôs experience as a black boy, and later man, in his body. The prose is insane in that it is impeccable. Kiese Laymon had extremely complicated relationships with people, society, and food. How he recounts them is brutally honest. The honesty made it an incredibly difficult read at times and yet I could not put it down. 

If you haven‚Äôt already, I hope you will read it.

There goes the next 3 years of my life! 

#aworldhistoryofwomenphotographers #lovetoread #womenrule #photography #women #womensupportingwomen #womenphotographers #heavybook #500pages

Here‚Äôs the first of the letters to the 7 churches in Asia Minor (Mostly in what is modern day Turkey) This is for the church of Ephesus. If I were to speak simply as to what the letter says: it‚Äôs a rundown of the positives and negatives and how they can improve and affirming the good work. They were good at discerning false teachers, particularly the Nicolaitians. These were followers of Nicolas-one of 7 men selected to serve the church in Acts 6:5, but he went the way of the heretic, incorporating much more idolatrous practices and sexual immorality like that of the pagans. Jesus warned them about letting their original love for him and others grow flat, and to return to that original love to flourish. Removing the lampstand if they didn‚Äôt change their tune. This doesn‚Äôt refer to the future end times, as that part of Turkey is now wholly Islamic. Clearly, they failed to heed the warning and make the changes needed. There are great promises made to the believers that overcome and heed what is said. To eat from the Tree of Life in paradise, which speaks of eternity. References: Revelation-Four Views by Steve Gregg. #revelation #revelationstudy #facewhatyoufear #thebible #heavybook #prophecy #thelettertoephesus #sevenletters

üè° In the Dream House by Carmen Maria Machado üè°

This memoir spoke to me on a SOUL LEVEL. I haven‚Äôt been so moved by a work of art like this in a long time and am so grateful for @carmenmmachado for helping me fall in love with writing all over again. Though the content of this book is quite heavy (about queer domestic abuse), the prose is so beautiful and gripping, I tore through it like a novel.

I was deeply inspired by how Machado played with form and told her story in the non-linear, disjointed manner trauma often presents itself. Her use of second person and short vignettes felt like one big permission slip to tell a story in exactly the way it‚Äôs supposed to be told. This will be one of those books that sits with me for a long, long time.
